Given your preference for stories set in the past and the intrigue around historical encounters, I'd recommend "Hitch" (2005). This film revisits one of the most famous meetings in cinema history between Alfred Hitchcock and François Truffaut. It offers a unique insight into their discussion, blending drama with the essence of cinematic history.

If you're interested in exploring a more period-driven story, "Mansfield Park" (1814) might be an intriguing choice. This classic novel, adapted into a film, tells the story of Fanny, a young woman born into poverty who is sent to live with her wealthy relatives. It's a captivating exploration of social class and personal growth in 19th-century England. Enjoy your movie time!

Based on your preference for a story that's not what you might expect, I would recommend "Man on Wire" (2008). This film tells an extraordinary tale about Philippe Petit's high-wire walk between the World Trade Center towers in 1974, a daring act some consider "the artistic crime of the century." It features Jean-Louis Blondeau, Paul McGill, and Philippe Petit as main actors.

Alternatively, if you're interested in historical dramas with strong performances, I suggest watching "A Tale of Two Cities" (1859). This classic story follows alcoholic lawyer Sydney Carton who travels to Paris during the Reign of Terror to rescue a French aristocrat and win over the woman he loves. It's an epic tale that is sure to captivate you!
